issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

projectCategory.description: Titanium and related SDKs used in application development
projectCategory.name: Client

resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.description:
When reading in a file that has a mime type of "application/json", the contents are seen as binary and then cannot be parsed correctly.

I created pull request 4465 to fix this issue:  https://github.com/appcelerator/titanium_mobile/pull/4465
fields.summary: MobileWeb: Data with JSON mime type seen as binary
fields.environment: Window 8 x64, Internet Explorer 10, Titanium SDK 3.1.1 GA

comments.body:
Is there any update on this? I am installing the latest SDK from github and everytime I install, I have to go and fix this file...   

It is a very small change.  Any chance this could get put into 3.2?  Thanks!!
Are there any updates on this issue?  How can we get this bug fix pushed into a build?  Thanks!!

[~emerriman] I don't have a test case. Turns out the Bryan had fixed this in the Windows Hybrid branch (prior to being merged with master) as well as we had a community PR from [~brentonhouse]. Bryan never had a test case as far as I know.

To test this, you can simply add a json file to your project, use Ti.Filesystem to read in the json file and you can check if the blob is binary and you can also print out its contents.

h5.Environment
Mac OSX 10.9.3
Windows 8.1
Appcelerator Studio, build: 3.3.0.201406111952
Titanium SDK, build: 3.3.0.v20140613124912
Titanium CLI, build: 3.3.0-rc
Alloy: 1.4.0-rc
Chrome: 35.0.1916.153
Firefox: 30.0.0
Safari: 7.0.4
Internet Explorer: 11.0.9600.17126

h5.Results
Using Firefox, the Mime-Type displayed: application/json
Using Chrome, the Mime-Type displayed: text/plain; charset=x-user-defined
Using Safari, the Mime-Type displayed: text/plain; charset=x-user-defined
Using Internet Explorer, the Mime-Type displayed: application/json

Also tested on other platforms and found the following:
Android: application/octet-stream
iOS: application/json
BlackBerry: Does not display a mime type

h5.Extra Information
All of the above can read the JSON file correctly and will not display any binary data.
Therefore, closing this ticket.
